I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The First Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change noted that the "greatest single 
impact of climate change could be on human migration with millions of people displaced by 
shoreline  erosion,  coastal  flooding  and  agricultural  disruption".1 Over  the  next  decade,  a 
considerable number of people could be affected by hydrological and meteorological hazards, 
particularly in South and Southeast Asia. People affected by these intensifying hazards will 
come  under  substantial  pressure  to  migrate  (temporarily  or  permanently,  and  internally  or 
across borders). Estimates of the number of people involved are highly controversial, and range 
from hundreds of millions to billions.2 
 
2.  Sudden  disasters  associated  with  climate  change  are  most  likely  to  occur  in  “hot 
spots”—low-lying coastal areas, heavily populated delta areas, low-lying islands and atolls, and 
other areas—where communities are already highly vulnerable to climate-related hazards. 
 
3.  The region has 4.1 billion people,3 and faces enormous environmental management 
pressures. There are also high numbers of climate change hot spots in the region—specific 
areas or regions that may be at relatively high risk of adverse impact from one or more natural 
hazards  resulting  from  climate  change 4 —with  high  population  densities  (particularly  in 
megacities). It is likely that migration will occur in these hot spots as the impacts of climate 
change are felt. While some displacements are typically temporary, the sudden expulsion of 
large numbers of people from their home area can place significant pressure on regional and 
national authorities to provide for their immediate needs. 
 
4.  Human displacement resulting from climate change will pose a major threat to the 
sustainable growth and security of Asia and the Pacific unless measures are taken soon. 
Climate-induced migration will undermine economic growth; increase pressure on infrastructure 
and services; enhance the risk of conflict; and lead to deterioration of social, health, and 
educational indicators. It represents an important potential brake on the region’s recent rapid 
economic growth.  
 
5.  An  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  study  underscored  the  urgency  of  developing 
policies, appropriate institutions and mechanisms to cope with the impact of climate change on 
migration.5 It emphasized that migration will become a major adaptive response to climate 
change and will add to the already increasing level and complexity of population mobility in the 
region, but stressed that the scale and scope of these impacts cannot be specified at present. It 
is possible, however, to identify the areas most likely to be impacted by climate change-induced 
migration,  and  outline  broad  policy  recommendations  to  address  surrounding  issues.  This 
technical assistance (TA)6 builds on the recommendations of the previous study.

II.  ISSUES 
6.  Asia and the Pacific is one of the world’s most natural disaster-prone regions. Eight of 
the 15 countries at highest risk of experiencing three or more natural hazards are in Asia and 
the Pacific, while half of the top 60 at risk of experiencing two or more hazards are in the 
region (footnote 3). There is a strong correlation between areas most at risk from natural 
hazards and areas at greatest risk of being impacted by climate change. Under the most 
scientifically robust projections, climate change is likely to add to population movement in Asia 
and the Pacific. 
 
7.  The  interaction  between  environmental  change  and  migration  is  poorly  understood, 
although the implications for migration—within countries and across international borders—
could be enormous. The consequences of climate change on human population displacement 
are complex, hard to predict, and hindered by a lack of baseline data and unclear projections of 
population  growth,  but  a  substantial  need  to  support  large-scale  migration  is  nevertheless 
anticipated. 
 
8.  There has been relatively little empirical research on the topic for Asia and the Pacific. It 
is very difficult to estimate how many people may move, or to determine their likely origins or 
destinations. Information on international migration is particularly poor, and current information 
does not provide a basis for realistic projections of future international mobility levels. 
 
9.  The impact of climate change on populations will be influenced by (i) the nature and 
severity of the climate change, and (ii) by the ability of populations to bring resources to bear to 
adapt to such change. The broader socioeconomic vulnerability of populations in the climate 
change hot spots is therefore significant.  
 
10.  Despite the region’s tremendous growth, many people still live in poverty;7 they have 
limited resources for adaptation, and their wellbeing remains highly vulnerable to environmental 
hazards and natural resource degradation. 
 
11.  The bulk of forced climate change-induced migration will involve poor people who will be 
the  most  vulnerable  to  climate  change  impacts.  Most  resettlement  will  occur  within  poor 
countries.  Landlessness,  homelessness,  socioeconomic  marginalization,  food  and  health 
insecurity, and loss of belonging are some of the most important effects of displacement due to 
climatic changes. The needs of migrants will include permanent shelter, energy and water 
supplies, sanitation, and school and health facilities; there will also be a need for a diverse 
range  of  adaptable  livelihood  security  opportunities,  capacity-building  of  national  and  sub-
national government entities, and relocation and settlement services. If these risks are not 
addressed  adequately,  they  may  result  in  chronic  vulnerability  and  increased  social  and 
economic marginalization of already disadvantaged social groups.  
 
12.  Current financial mechanisms for climate change adaptation are limited, however, and 
are not sufficient to address the growing need to cope with the uncertainties of displacement. 
Moreover, large-scale migration is not taken into account in most national adaptation strategies. 
In the event of a climate-induced migration, a sizeable financing facility will be required.  
 
13.  There is an urgent need for the development of appropriate policies, institutions, and 
mechanisms to help target intervention strategies. Major improvements will be required in many 
                                                 
7  ADB estimates 903 million people live on $1.25 per day.

3
areas—more  effective  migration  management,  stronger  governance,  development  of 
appropriate funding mechanisms, enhancement of international cooperation on climate change 
issues, expansion and improvement of development assistance mechanisms, and development 
of sound economic development policy and practice throughout the region. These changes 
require substantial institutional, structural, and cultural change, and will require considerable 
lead time. 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
14.  This  regional  research  and  development  TA  will  undertake  studies  to  improve 
understanding of climate-induced migration in selected developing member countries (DMCs) 
and  subregions.8 Analysis  will  be  undertaken  and  policy  recommendations  developed  with 
respect  to  the  economic  and  sociopolitical  consequences  of  climate-induced  migration; 
institutional, capacity and resource gaps; and the feasibility of a financing mechanism to support 
the costs of climate-induced migration. Information dissemination campaigns to raise awareness 
and share the results of the studies, complementing the communications plan of ADB's Climate 
Change Program, will also be undertaken. 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
15.  The impact of the TA is reduced vulnerability of DMCs from the impacts of climate-
induced migration. The expected outcome is enhanced capacity and improved understanding of 
the  impacts  and  action  required  to  address  climate-induced  migration.  The  design  and 
monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
16.  The TA will have the following outputs: (i) country and subregional studies to improve the 
empirical basis for policy and planning on climate-induced migration, (ii) a feasibility study on 
options to finance needs related to climate-induced migration, (iii) regional dialogues and policy 
recommendations to address climate-induced migration, and (iv) awareness-raising activities 
and regional workshops on the conclusions of the TA. The activities to achieve the outputs are: 
 
1.  Output 1: Country and Subregional Studies to Improve the Empirical Basis 
for Policy and Planning on Climate-Induced Migration 
(i)  Follow-on studies in countries and subregions. Building on the findings of the 
recently  concluded climate  change  and  migration  study,  the  TA  will  conduct 
joint,9 subregional, and country studies in identified hotspots on the major drivers, 
likely impacts, potential needs and possible policy measures to address climate-
induced migration, by (a) examining past experience, patterns, and distinguishing

features among the drivers of migration; and (b) identifying barriers and actions 
to address these.  
(ii)  Tracking  and  monitoring  migration. Building on past and ongoing work of 
other  partners,  the  TA  will  (a)  examine  current  means  of  displacement  and 
migration data collection, tracking, and monitoring, and recommend measures for 
improvement; and (b) where possible, review distinctions between climactic and 
non-climactic factors affecting migration in order to isolate or correlate the causes 
of migration.  
(iii)  Tool development. The TA will undertake an analysis and prepare tools for 
replication in other hotspots, including: (a) socioeconomic analysis, examining 
potential social, economic and financial implications of climate-induced migration 
in selected countries in the region and the costs and benefit of adaptation and 
resettlement  or  temporary  movements;  (b)  gap  assessments  on  capacity, 
governance,  infrastructure,  service  delivery  and  adaptable  livelihood 
opportunities  of  DMCs,  communities  and  civil  society  organizations  in  both 
recipient and origin territories, and the financing requirements to address the 
gaps;  (c)  risk  assessment,  reviewing  adaptation  policies  and  measures,  and 
building in a framework for assessing climate, other hazards and risk mapping in 
hotspots, recipient and sending countries or territories and identifying adaptation 
policies and measures to minimize disruptions and negative impacts of large-
scale migration in regional or country frameworks on climate change.  
(iv)  Options for development. The TA will review past resettlement experience and 
draw lessons appropriate for climate-induced migration, exploring a range of 
settlement options for displaced populations (staying in camps, integration with 
local populations in destinations, joining relatives, etc.) as well resettlement or 
return options.  
 
2.  Output  2:    Feasibility  Study  on  Financing  Facility  and  Mechanisms  for 
Operation 
(i)  Financing options. The TA will undertake a comprehensive feasibility study for 
the expansion of existing funding facilities (including the Adaptation Fund of the 
Kyoto Protocol and the United Nations Central Emergency Response Fund) or 
the establishment and maintenance of a new funding facility. This includes a 
review of current initiatives, and proposing areas of collaboration, synergy and 
(where appropriate) expansion. A review of other financing modalities—e.g., risk 
insurance, adaptation funds, and use of remittances as a source of development 
funds—will also be undertaken.  
(ii)  Mechanism for operation. The TA will  review existing mechanisms for fund 
sourcing,  including  major  principles  and  mechanisms  of  burden  sharing  to 
establish financing facilities, and propose procedures and structures, including 
regarding: trustees, trust management, major donors and stakeholders (including 
civil  society  organizations,  public  and  private  sectors),  replenishment, 
disbursement  criteria,  triggers  for  fund  use,  monitoring  and  evaluation,  the 
projected principal needed, and the level of annual contributions required to 
match future needs. 
 
3.  Output 3:  Regional Dialogues and Policy Framework Development 
17.  The TA will sponsor bilateral, regional, and international dialogues on the status and 
protection of climate-induced migrants in the context of the policy dialogues under climate

5
change implementation plan processes. It will also examine international immigration policy, 
national adaptation strategies and international legal instruments in selected regions, DMCs, 
and developed countries, and identify potential processes, instruments, adaptation policies and 
measures appropriate for climate change-induced migration, including how agreements can 
include provisions on assistance and protection. Based on this review, it will develop and 
propose agreements, policies, and frameworks addressing climate-induced migration and the 
strengthening of existing mechanisms on migration.  
 
4.  Output 4:  Awareness Raising and Information Dissemination 
18.  A  communications  and  dissemination  plan  that  makes  use  of  multimedia  will  be 
prepared to raise awareness in both potential recipient and origin territories. The findings of the 
TA will be disseminated through awareness-raising campaigns and conferences attended by a 
range of stakeholders. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
19.  The total cost of the TA is estimated to be $700,000. The TA will be financed by the ADB 
Climate Change Fund on a grant basis. The detailed cost estimates and financing plan are in 
Appendix 2.  
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
20.  ADB will be the executing agency for the TA. It will be implemented over 12 months 
(January–December 2010). ADB—through the Climate Change Program Unit, in collaboration 
with the Poverty Reduction, Gender, and Social Development Division of the ADB Regional and 
Sustainable  Development  Department—will  be  responsible  for  overall  management  and 
monitoring of TA activities. Throughout the TA implementation, the Climate Change Program 
Unit  will  closely  consult  with  regional  departments,  resident  missions  concerned,  and 
implementation partners. At least three country or regional hotspots will be included in the TA.10 
A  no-objection  in  writing  will  be  obtained  before  commencing  or  financing  any  proposed 
activities in the territory of the participating DMCs. The progress and outputs of the TA will be 
posted and regularly updated on the ADB climate change and social development websites.  
 
21.  The TA will require an estimated total of 31 person-months of consulting services (5 
international consultants with expertise in climate change economics, national and international 
migration, financing, social development and public information for a total of 19 person-months 
and 12 person-months of national consultants with similar expertise as that of the international 
consultants). International consultants, in coordination with development partners and regional 
operational departments, will lead the studies, dialogues, and awareness campaigns. National 
consultants will provide support to the international consultants. All consultants will be engaged 
by ADB as individuals in accordance with its Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2007, as 
amended from time to time). Outline terms of reference for the consultants are in Appendix 3. 
The Poverty Reduction, Gender, and Social Development Division will set up an external and 
internal review and advisory panels for the project during the course of the TA. 
 
                                                 
10 These studies, spread across ADB operational subregions, will be selected in consultation with operations 
departments on the basis of potential risks and demand and the existence of partner institutions.

IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
22.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $700,000 on a grant basis for 
the Policy Options to Support Climate-Induced Migration, and hereby reports this action to the 
Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.  A team of five individual international consultants (total of 20 person-months) will form 
the core technical assistance (TA) study group. The international consultants will have expertise 
in  (i)  climate  change  economics  and  scenario  development,  (ii)  migration,  (iii)  social 
development, (iv) institutional and financial modeling and analysis, and (v) communications and 
media. Each individual consultant will be responsible for finalizing his or her outputs in close 
coordination with the Asian Development Bank (ADB) team leader and key stakeholders. The 
regional  research  and  development  TA  will  coordinate  closely  with  regional  departments, 
especially in the selection of study areas, identification of study scope and the conduct of the 
TA. 
 
A.  International Consultants (20 person-months, intermittent) 
2.  The climate change economist (lead consultant) (7 person-months, intermittent) will 
have undertaken similar work in the past with a minimum of 10 years work experience in 
economic modeling, scenario building, and climate change. The successful candidate will: 
 
(i)  undertake a desk review of related literature and programs on climate-induced 
migration, summarizing key issues, learning and innovative initiatives; 
(ii)  manage and supervise the preparation of an inception and final reports, taking 
into account the key deliverables under outputs 1, 2, and 3, in close collaboration 
with the other consultants and regional operations departments; 
(iii)  identify areas and scope for country and regional studies; 
(iv)  undertake the study on socioeconomic impacts and needs arising out of climate-
induced  migration,  by  developing  scenarios  for  climate-induced  migration  in 
selected  areas,  using  the  First  Intergovernmental  Panel  on  Climate  Change 
projections of the physical impacts of climate change at different time periods, 
and identifying the socioeconomic implications of each scenario;  
(v)  prepare a framework for undertaking a cost–benefit and socioeconomic analysis 
of  climate-induced  migration  and  adaptation  for  potential  replication  in  other 
developing member countries (DMCs), develop a framework for assessing risk 
mapping related to climate and other hazards and risks in potential hotspots, and 
identify adaptation policies and measures to minimize disruptions and negative 
impacts brought about by large-scale migration that can be integrated in existing 
regional or country frameworks to address climate change;  
(vi)  identify gaps in capacity, infrastructure, service delivery, and adaptable livelihood 
opportunities in both potential recipient and origin territories and the financing 
needed to support them in addressing the gaps; 
(vii)  review past resettlement experience and draw lessons appropriate for climate-
induced  migration,  exploring  a  range  of  settlement  options  for  displaced 
populations  (staying  in  camps,  integration  with  local  populations  in  the 
destination territories, joining relatives, etc.) as well as the option of resettlement 
or return;  
(viii)  in coordination with other members of the team, prepare policy and strategic 
measures to address climate-induced migration; 
(ix)  present the outcome of the studies in regional workshops to be organized by the 
TA; 
(x)  act as a resource person for ADB and DMCs and identify specific conceptual, 
policy and operational issues regarding the social dimensions of climate-induced 
migration;

staff on the TA; 
(xii)  liaise with other development and funding agencies and governments to promote 
coordination and consistency with respect to the approach and recommendations 
of the study; and  
(xiii)  perform other tasks relevant to this TA.  
 
3.  The migration specialist (4 person-months, intermittent) will have extensive knowledge 
on migration and related international and national legal and policy instruments. He or she will: 
 
(i)  undertake a desk review of related literature and programs on climate-induced 
migration (internal and across countries) summarizing key issues, learning, and 
innovative initiatives;  
(ii)  examine past experience, patterns, and drivers of migration and identify barriers 
as well as proposed actions to successfully manage climate-induced migration; 
(iii)  examine international immigration policy, national migration policies and related 
barriers;  national  adaptation  strategies  and  international  legal  instruments  in 
selected  regions,  DMCs,  and  developed  countries;  and  identify  potential 
processes, instruments, policies, and measures appropriate for climate-induced 
migration; 
(iv)  develop  and  propose  bilateral  and  regional  agreements,  policies,  and 
frameworks to address climate-induced migration, including the strengthening of 
existing international, regional and national mechanisms;  
(v)  review  existing  tracking  and  monitoring  tools  and  mechanisms  on  migration 
(internal and across borders), including means of data collection, tracking and 
monitoring  of  displacement  and  migration,  and  recommend  measures  for 
improvement, including by specifying institutions that can potentially undertake 
such monitoring, and identifying areas in which the capacity of these institutions 
can be strengthened; 
(vi)  identify gaps in migration governance arrangements and capacity in DMCs and 
regional or international bodies, and propose actions and financing needed to 
address the gaps; and  
(vii)  perform other tasks relevant to this TA. 
 
4.  The  financing  institutions  and  financial  modeling  specialist  (4  person-months, 
intermittent) will have at least 10 years of extensive experience in developing financial or 
funding tools, including relating to risk management, and will:  
 
(i)  in selected hotspot DMCs, prepare an analysis of the costs (socioeconomic, 
political, cultural, etc.) of climate-induced migration and of different options (e.g., 
adaptation,  resettlement  or  temporary  movements),  and  identify  sources  of 
financing (internally or otherwise);  
(ii)  in the selected hotspots, prepare an indicative financing plan to address issues 
that are likely to result from climate-induced migration; 
(iii)  in collaboration with the team leader, prepare a tool or framework for replication 
of cost analysis in other hotspots; 
(iv)  identify  and  analyze  financing  gaps  and  institutions  providing  financing,  and 
recommend measures to address the gaps; 
(v)  undertake a comprehensive feasibility study  for expansion of current funding 
facilities (including the United Nations Central Emergency Response Fund) or the 
establishment  and  maintenance  of  a  new  funding  facility  (including  potential

business models; 
(vi)  review the operation and rules of existing mechanisms on fund sourcing and 
propose procedures and structures relating to trustees, trust management, major 
donors and stakeholders, replenishment, disbursement criteria, triggers for fund 
use, and the projected principal needed to match future needs; and  
(vii)  perform other tasks relevant to this TA.  
 
5.  The social development specialist (2 person-months, intermittent) will have extensive 
experience in the social dimensions of climate change and social analysis. He or she will: 
 
(i)  undertake a desk review of literature and programs on climate-induced migration, 
focusing on the social dimensions of climate change, and summarize key issues, 
learning, and innovations;  
(ii)  assist  the  team  leader  in  reviewing  the  social  impacts  of  climate-induced 
migration and the social dimensions of migration, including aspects of gender, 
health and poverty, and conflict; 
(iii)  review  the  capacity  and  experiences  of  DMCs,  development  partners, 
nongovernment organizations, and other relevant stakeholders in addressing the 
social dimensions of climate change; and  
(iv)  perform other tasks relevant to this TA 
 
6.  The communications and media specialist (3 person-months, intermittent) shall have at 
least 10 years of relevant experience in developing awareness-raising and media campaigns on 
social causes. He or she shall: 
 
(i)  prepare a multimedia communications plan to disseminate findings and raise 
awareness in both potential recipient and origin territories;  
(ii)  undertake pilot information and awareness raising campaigns on the findings and 
recommendations of the TA; 
(iii)  assist in organizing conferences and roadshows for the TA; and 
(iv)  perform other tasks relevant to the TA. 
 
B.  National Consultants (12 person-months, intermittent) 
7.  The national officer (6 person-months, intermittent) will be based in Manila and perform 
tasks under the supervision of the team leader and project officer. The national consultant will 
have a strong background in climate change and social development. The national consultant 
will undertake the following activities: 
 
(i)  provide research support to the international consultants; 
(ii)  assist  the  international  consultants  in  collecting  study-related  data,  drafting 
sections of the study report, and preparing the report for presentation in the 
regional workshop; 
(iii)  provide logistical and administrative support to workshops, knowledge exchange, 
and the preparation of dialogues and publications; 
(iv)  participate in and document meetings and workshops;  
(v)  assist in and facilitate communication among the members of the review and 
advisory panel, international consultants, and DMC representatives; 
(vi)  review and check the quality of reports and ensure consistency with ADB style
